title: include lodash in documentation page
body: Hey, what do you think of loading lodash in the documentation page so we can play with it straight from the browser console?

title: Summon devs associated with fixed Underscore.js bugs.
body:
Hi All,

You all are summoned here because I've fixed, in [Lo-Dash](http://lodash.com), various [Underscore.js bugs](https://github.com/bestiejs/lodash#closed-underscorejs-issues) that you either reported or `+1`'ed to have fixed.

If you don't see your bug fixed [here](https://github.com/bestiejs/lodash#closed-underscorejs-issues), then it is fixed in the edge version of Lo-Dash:
- Ensure `_.escape` returns an empty string when passed `null` or `undefined` [[#407](https://github.com/documentcloud/underscore/issues/427), [test](https://github.com/bestiejs/lodash/blob/babdacc17c5ca0339c9bddfb9f4d2c3027e34d48/test/test.js#L161-164)]

title: Make `_.shuffle` work on objects.
body: Underscore just fixed their `_.shuffle` to [work with objects](https://github.com/documentcloud/underscore/commit/6b196fd61a4e29ffba4e5a134fb2854276177ab3) because internally they were using `_.each` and unintended object usage slipped in. This is kinda lame as it complicates things but I am wondering do you all think Lo-Dash should support this untested feature yet? //cc @floydsoft

title: lodash CLI
body:
Check out this commit on my fork of lodash:

https://github.com/iammerrick/lodash/commit/2785764c8870b323a28f672311df1fb79056b5bd

It essentially lets you `npm link` your lodash and then you have the `lodash` command anywhere. This would also work for npm install lodash -g; then people could just use `lodash` wherever. The only problem with the npm -g is the way the repository is currently set up via submodule and the like, you can't leverage the build without cloning and initializing the repository submodules. What are your thoughts on making this work in the real lodash.

title: Possible improvement?
Add fail-safe to "Arrays" category methods to allow falsy values for `array` argument
body:
As issue #23 points out, sometimes it's nice to have array methods not error when they receive a falsy value for the required `array` argument.

The use case is something like

``` js
// should handle when `String#match` returns `null` without erroring
_.flatten(string.match(/regexp/))
```

So I would like to know if you all (/cc @kitcambridge @mathiasbynens) think it's worthwhile.

title: underscore-like behaviour of flatten
body: I don't sure it is bug or a feature.

title: _.where collection filter function
body:
The `_.where` method accepts a collection of objects and based on a key: value object, a shallow copy match is returned.  This is used in the case where you have a filter function that is only ever checking a `key=>val` match.

``` javascript
var people = [
  { name: "Tom", age: 19 },
  { name: "John". age: 3 },
  { name: "Seven", age: 37 },
  { name: "John", age: 42 }
];
```

The arguments are a collection of objects and an object literal to compare:

``` javascript
var seven = _.where(people, { name: "Seven" });
```

While the above example shows a single key, val filter you can also combo:

``` javascript
var littleJohn = _.where(people, { name: "John", age: 3 });
```

If no match is found, return `null`.  If multiple objects are found, return an Array.

title: _.max incompatibility with Underscore.js
body:
lodash will only handle arrays and does not handle objects in its implementation of max.

Code:

``` javascript
_.max({a:1, b:2})
```

Expected result with Underscore.js:

``` javascript
2
```

Actual result with lodash:

``` javascript
-Infinity
```

title: Add `fromIndex` argument to _.indexOf and _.lastIndexOf
body:
The lack of [fromIndex](http://es5.github.com/#x15.4.4.14) support in `_.indexOf` and `_.lastIndexOf` has bothered me for a while.
Currently `_.lastIndexOf` lacks support and `_.indexOf` has an [isSorted](https://github.com/documentcloud/underscore/commit/d2d6cfe6675d18b058e52785c438a3c1a7502208) boolean argument instead.

I could work this into `_.indexOf` with some overloading to allow `_.indexOf(value, isSorted)` and `_.indexOf(value, fromIndex, isSorted)`.

Thoughts?

title: Attempting to load minified Lo-Dash results in Uncaught ReferenceError
body:
See this fiddle:

http://jsfiddle.net/XCsuX/

Attempting to load the minified Lo-Dash (https://raw.github.com/bestiejs/lodash/master/lodash.min.js) results in the following error in the console:

"Uncaught ReferenceError: obj is not defined"

Changing the fiddle to load the unminified version (https://raw.github.com/bestiejs/lodash/master/lodash.js) works as expected without error.

This is reproducible every time for me on:

Windows 7 x64
Google Chrome 21.0.1145.0
Mozilla Firefox 12.0

title: Optimize `escape()` by not needlessly escaping the `/` character
body:
Given the list of characters that are escaped already, I can’t think of a reason why you’d want/need to escape `/` in a quoted attribute value or an element’s content. `escape()` is only meant to be used in these three situations: ``` html

HERE

``` --- Whoops, typo in commit message — to clarify, this is about the `/` character, not the `\` character. I’ll fix the commit message upon mergin the pull (if it gets approved).

title: Fixing issue #16, _.template incompatibility with Underscore.js
body: Fix for issue #16 - _.template incompatibility with Underscore.js.

title: _.template incompatibility with Underscore.js
body:
Underscore.js defines a default variable called 'obj' for use in referencing your JS data from your HTML templates (see https://github.com/documentcloud/underscore/blob/master/underscore.js#L1027).

lodash will read the default data variable name from lodash.templateSettings.variable, which does not exist - just like in Underscore.js.

lodash fails if an underscore template use 'obj' without explicitly setting the variable name to 'obj' in the call to _.template.

This breaks the "drop-in replacement" requirement.

title: _.find result not consistent with Underscore.js
body:
See jsfiddle here: http://jsfiddle.net/Ln9xc/2/

Underscore.js behaves like so:

``` js
_([1,2,3,4]).find(function(i) { return i === 5 }); // returns undefined
```

While Lo-Dash returns the entire list if it can't find a match:

``` js
_([1,2,3,4]).find(function(i) { return i === 5 }); // returns [1,2,3,4]
```

This was unexpected for me. If this is desired behavior, perhaps add a note?

title: Add environment specific builds and inline compiled methods.
body: On mobile, every ms counts. Startup cost and runtime cost are both very important. Is there anything in lodash that isn't absolutely necessary in a browser such as mobile Safari or Crome for Android? Is it possible to do an optimized build of lodash that is as optimized as possible for those specific environments?

title: jsPerf benchmark readability
body:
I have been told that the jsPerf tests do not appear to show the claimed 8x perf boost.

Any chance you can make more jsPerf tests that only compare 1 thing at a time? E.g. forEach: native, underscore, lodash, jQuery, etc…

Thanks!

title: Startup cost of meta programming?
body: I have been asked to benchmark the startup cost of lodash vs underscore. Now I am asking you because I'm on my iPhone and stuff and maybe lazy also.

title: Bound functions used as constructors
Why use this instead of underscore.js?
body:
I don't see an obvious reason why I should switch from underscore.js to lodash.

Maybe the reasons are documented somewhere, but I didn't see them.

Can you update the README or the project's web site to clearly outline/prove the benefits or advantages to using lodash over underscore.js?

Thank you!

title: Add Node.js benchmark. Fixes #8
body: ![screenshot](https://img.skitch.com/20120515-gks14k4csutkk3ct3t886ubtg9.png)

title: Node.js benchmark
body:
It's obvious from the performance tests that Lodash is faster than Underscore in the browser, but I couldn't find any Node.js benchmarks.

You need some Node.js performance benchmarks to show how must faster Lodash is on Node.js.

title: Add the isPrimitive function using a hash check.
body:
@John We might end up using this at GS!  You are awesome as usual.

Let me know if this will work for isPrimitive.  I ran some jsperf tests and this seems to be fast across the board but slower than a few other alternatives on Chrome.  The other alternative namely being cached strings in an array with conditionals for the type/null check.  I think this is the easiest to read approach though.

title: Faster slice.
Add support for partial application
body:
A performant implementation of partial application that does not alter
the context of the functions. Although similar to `_.bind` it promotes
greater composability and flexibility through not altering the context
at all. A common tool in functional programming that is of such utility
it should be in core.

title: Added isHash, matches {} but not subclasses (which isObject does)
Fixing typo of "clearInterval".
body: Worth noting though – this function isn't used elsewhere. Perhaps it should be removed.

title: Auto-minification
body: `build.js` will now save the smallest minified distribution as `lodash.min.js`. See issue #1 for the discussion.

title: Replace the `Makefile` with a JavaScript-based build system.
